Name: Emmacubes Sumfun
Description:
There are 24 cubes with numbers and other mathematical symbols on the sides in the box.

From the box cover: Divide the cubes between 2-4 players who then proceed to construct their own separate sum (all cubes must be used) as example below:- 
9x9=81
A player on completion of sum may call sumfun when all play must stop. Answers of completed (and correct) sums count as score. Redeal and play up to five games for set.

Name: Professor Quizzle's Quiz Wizard Trivia: Television
Description: Basic deck of cards with trivia questions about television programs. Can be added to any other trivia game for extended fun.

Name: Arena DeathMatch
Description:
From publisher's website:

Welcome to Arena Deathmatch!

Avatars of War: Arena DeathMatch is a 28mm miniatures game that depicts the bloody clash between two or more bands of heroes facing off on the floor of the arena, in front of a raucous crowd that is thirsty for action, violence and death.  This deadly contest is known as a deathmatch.

The most powerful heroes among the mortal races are known as Avatars of War--heroes chosen by the Gods of War themselves.  These Avatars, in addition to being fierce combatants, are able to draw upon the silver of divinity within their souls for the power to expand their already awesome combat abilities.

In Arena DeathMatch, each player controls a band of Avatars of War as they face off on the arena floor in front of a cheering (or jeering) crowd.

The perils of the Arena stand against you: traps, hazards and even savage beasts stand between you and your opponent.  The door to the Arena opens, and the shouting crowd is eager to see their favourite heroes fight to the death.  Will they be cheering your victory...or your death?  There's only one way to find out!

Name: Brew-HaHa
Description:
Brew-HaHa - The Official Beer Nutz Comix Game by Wild Wigout Comix Game Boards.

A wonderful handmade silk-screened board game created by underground comic artist Wayno in the mid 1990s for the now extinct Scairy Hairy Toys which was previously located in San Fransisco, Ca.

To play the game you need a case or three of cheap, cheap beer, shot glasses, and the song Rubber Biscuit by The Chips (easily found on the web)....

The object of the game is to out-drink your opponents while moving your drunken game piece around the board and staying conscious yourself. The winner of the game is the last one standing and/or resisting the urge to throw-up especially when dancing and singing along to the great hit song "Rubber Biscuit" performed by The Chips circa 1956. Yes, anytime a player lands on the Rubber Biscuit space everyone has to jump up and shout Rubber Biscuit, Rubber Biscuit!!! while dancing to the song. Any player returning their cheap beer rental via the porcelain god is immediately disqualified and is banished to pass out in the bathtub.

Name: Wygraj z maturą
Description:
Polish game designed specially to help students to pass the high school exams. It's designed for the Ministry of Education by a group of grad teachers. It has 3000 questions in five different categories: Polish language/literature, history, geography, English language, others (culture, art, philosophy...).

Components:
- board
- dice
- pawns
- 360 cards with questions
- 60 cards "chance".

Official website: http://www.wygrajzmatura.pl

Name: Knight's Domain
Description:
Knight's Domain is played with similar rules to chess.  Each side has only three types of pieces, 8 Knights, 3 pawns, and 1 King.  The object is to Checkmate your opponents King.  The King is restricted to movement within a 6 space area called the "King's Vale" at the rear of his board.

Game components as published include:
1 9x8 board with "Vale" area clearly marked
2 kings
16 Knights
6 pawns
instructions.

Name: Beneath the Lily Banners Second Edition: Wargame Rules for 1660 - 1721
Description: A tabletop wargaming rule system designed to give players a real flavour for the tactics and troops used in Europe during the period 1660-1721. The game play is simple and quick to master. The mechanics are based on simultaneous movement regulated by easy to understand orders. The game can be played in 28mm or 15mm scale. 6-8 units per side will give two or three hours of fun. The rules will easily accommodate 100 units per side for grand battle scenarios. The 2nd edition has many refined mechanisms for orders, shooting, close combat and morale. The book has an updated events section with 52 ‘playing card’ controlled game events to add challenges and entertainment to the game play. The rules contain supplementary chapters for gaming the Great Northern War, Eastern Wars against the Ottoman Empire and King William’s War in North America 1689-1690.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Quinquereme
Description:
Quinquereme is an extension module to the War Galley: Naval Warfare in the Ancient World game by GMT.  This module is found in GMT's C3I Issue #12.

Scenarios:

     Ebro, 217 BC Rome vs. Carthage 
     Clupea, 208 BC Rome vs. Carthage


Expands:

    War Galley: Naval Warfare in the Ancient World
Families: Series: Great Battles of History (GMT Games)

Name: Down in Flames: Arab-Israeli War 1948-'49
Description:
A Down in Flames Campaign from RBM/GMT's C3i Magazine Nr12.

Contents:
Background and rules
Campaign Sheet
2 sheets of Down in Flames aircraft

Name: Moose Boose
Description:
Bring a miniaturized classic country fair atmosphere into your own home. Filled with moose calls, bidding and trading, Moose Boose gives a whole new meaning to the half-and-half concept.

Own the winning square by purchasing from or trading with your opponents. But be careful! The winning square might already be yours right from the start! Moose Boose is a strategic game of luck and is ideal for entertaining the whole family and friends.

Apportez à la maison l'ambiance des foires agricoles en un classique miniaturisé. Agrémenté de cris d'orignal, d'enchères et d'échanges, Moose Boose réinvente le concept des moitié-moitié.

Procurez-vous la case gagnante en achetant ou en échangeant avec vos adversaires. Mais attention! Il se peut que vous possédiez la bonne case dès le départ! Moose Boose est un jeu de hasard stratégique, idéal et «orignal» pour amuser toute la famille et les amis.

Name: Super Gachapon Fighter
Description:
Super Gachapon Fighter is a tabletop/miniatures fighting game ruleset designed for 2-4 players.

Players create their own personalized fighter (using any figures or miniatures you have at hand) and take to the streets for one on one or team based combat. Make any tabletop a arena to stage your bouts.

Use fireballs, combos or grapples to pound your opponent into submission. Or build up your charge meter and unleash a Super Move!

Visit www.gachafighter.com and download the Demo rules!!

Name: Guard du Corps
Description: Guard du Corps can be used with 25mm, 15mm or even 5/6mm scale models.  Guard du Corps is played on a 1 to 60 scale with 1 turn equalling 15 minutes.  The game comes with a Rules book, and Army (unit) Data book, and a set of 12 game charts.

Name: Emil räumt auf!
Description: In this game based on children's books by Janosch, the players have to recycle several types of garbage, like scrap paper, bulk garbage or organic waste. The player, who can dispose of his waste on the right spots on the board first, wins.

Name: Equine Trivia
Description:
Equine Trivia, The Game

Players answer questions about horses and equestrian sports as they attempt to advance to the Championship Round.

Includes a colorful board, tokens, dice, score chips, rules, question cards, storage box, and rules.

The game features an unusual packaging concept: it comes in a plastic tote box.

(c)1984

Name: Coppa Santagostino
Description: Italian cycling game released to promote a manufacturer of socks (!?). Played on a board measuring 49x34cm.

Name: Escape from Zyzzlvaria
Description:
Escape from Zyzzlvaria is a board game whose existence was first announced at the 2002 MIT Mystery Hunt in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and then debuted seven years later at ZyzzlCon during the 2009 MIT Mystery Hunt. Only 75 production copies were printed.

The game features a board, 12 polyhedral dice, a deck of 16 cards, 8 pawns, 8 escape pods, 370 dollar bucks, a Moon Counter, and a Wheel of Death. The object of the game is to get as many members of the crew of the Brass Rat out of Zyzzlvaria before the moon counter reaches Eclipse!

The game's primary designer is Foggy Brume, based on concepts from a puzzle by Dan Katz.

http://escapefromzyzzlvaria.com/

http://www.mit.edu/~puzzle/09/puzzles/The_Board_Game/

Name: La Segunda Guerra Mundial 2ªParte, Frente del Pacífico
Description:
The 7th of December 1941, Japanese troops without previously declaring war, launched an attack to the US NAVY, based at Pearl Harbor.

This game represents the war in the Pacific Ocean

Name: Das Camp
Description:
Youth leaders can test their knowledge with this game. The game is about the organization, performance and evaluation of children in a youth camp.
The game is played with 2 to 4 teams with at least 3 gamers. The game map is divided in three parts which symbolize the three phases of a youth camp. The teams have to go trough these phases and resolve the duties and responsibilities which they get by cards. The team which is first to reach their goal wins.

Name: Benthos
Description:
"7 Major International Companies are developing the Worlds Ocean Resources. Players buy stocks in these companies and control how they grow. Board Game for 2-7 players."

The game is played on a 10x10 grid using tiles and cubes. Also required for play are Stock cards, paper money (or any reasonable substitute), and a scoring track. The board is randomly filled with tiles at the start of the game.

The game lasts for five rounds. During each round there are seven turns. Each turn starts with the players bidding for control of a single share of stock from one of the seven companies. The player winning the bid operates the company for that round (represented by placing cubes on the board). These operations determine the value of the company, which in turn determines the amount of money paid as dividends to the stockholders for that company.

Once seven turns have been played, one for each company, the round ends and dividends are paid to stockholders. The winner is the player with the most money at the end of the game.

Name: Build the Kingdom: The Greatest Mission in the World
Description:
Build the Kingdom - The Greatest Mission in the World is an LDS-themed game in which players attempt to gain the most converts in a game somewhat similar to CATAN.

The board is a modular assortment of diamonds (rather than the hexes used in CATAN) with each having a symbol representing a principle of the Mormon faith on it (Preach my Kingdom, Faith, Repentance, Baptism, and Prayer). Players gain the principles through die rolls and trade them in for converts, Books of Mormons, and churches - each of which is worth Celestial Points. Satan (similar to Catan's Robber) moves about the game board hindering the work.

The game ends when a player achieves 10 Celestial Points.

Name: Tenplus
Description: A collection of three card based games from designer Susumu Kawasaki: Sums Ten, Countup Ten, and Hand Ten.  The former plays with two or three players, while the others work for two to four players.

Name: Classic BattleTech: Starterbook – Wolf and Blake
Description:
Starterbook: Wolf and Blake is the second volume in the Classic Battletech Starterbook series. Each book in the series is designed to act as a "bridge" between various Battletech products, making it easier for players to jump into an enriched but more complex game. While Classic BattleTech: Starterbook â€“ Sword and Dragon serves as a link between the BattleTech: Introductory Box Set and the full tournament/standard rules found in BattleTech: Total Warfare, Starterbook: Wolf and Blake links Total Warfare to BattleTech: Tactical Operations, the on-world advanced core rulebook. Wolf and Blake also offers an introduction to the current Jihad storyline and to the religiously driven Word of Blake faction. The famed Black Widow Company serves as the opposing force.

Wolf and Blake follows the basic pattern laid out in Sword and Dragon: brief bits of fiction, profiles of each side's history and current Mechwarriors, a rules annex (here previewing some of the advanced rules from TacOps), a "warchest" campaign system, and a series of branching missions that players can explore. The book ends with a series of filled-in record sheets, including variant 'Mechs depicted in the text.

Total Warfare is required to use Starterbook: Wolf and Blake. Technical Readout: 3050 Upgrade is recommended.

Name: Convention
Description:
A tabletop dexterity game where players flick wooden half-cylinders into each other, scoring points when a flicked piece hits another of the same orientation.

The 48 wooden pieces are tossed on the table. Those lying flat side down are called "Republicans", and those lying curved side down are called "Democrats". In addition, four of the wooden pieces are colored blue and deemed "Independents". Players attempt to flick a piece into another of the same affiliation, without hitting any other piece. Special rules detail the proper way of handling Independents and any maverick pieces that happen to land standing on end.

An odd marriage of Crokinole and Pass the Pigs.

Name: Bobby Hull Hockey Game
Description: Similar to the Munro Hockey game from 1931. This one of course is much more modern with a metal frame and metal players. This game has a automatic puck drop, scoreboard, goal lights that actually light up (requires 2 D-size batteries). The game also came with double players which could be used when you pulled your goalie for an added skater near the end of a close game. The game featured metal players from various original teams in the NHL.

Name: Guard the Hive's Golden Treasure!
Description:
Guard the Hive's Golden Treasure! was published on the back of a Honey Nut Cheerios cereal box in 2008. The cereal box comes with a Magic Compass Decoder that is used in playing the game.

From the box:

Guard the Hive's Golden Treasure!

Buzz and his friends want to move the honey that makes Honey Nut Cheerios cereal so delicious across the amber ocean. But Yellow Jack and his crew won't make it easy!

To Play:
Help Buzz transport the honey across the ocean or challenge a friend to see who can get there first. To play, flip a coin to determine how many spaces to move. Heads move one space, tails moves two.

When you land on a compass, place your magic compass decoder on the spot and move it back and forth to reveal the symbol for your next move. Use the key to determine the value for each symbol.

Name: Share A Berry
Description:
The small bear collect berries. Do you want to accompany it? How many berries have you collected? Count with the small bear and experience the exciting counting world.

Every round you open a card and you receive berries. Last two rounds you have to give some berries to you left or right neighbors.
It trains little kids to count and share things with others.

Name: Heirs of the Golden Horde
Description:
Heirs of the Golden Horde (HGH) is the sixth volume of Red Sash Games Lace Wars series. The game is companion to Volume V, Türkenkrieg. The subject of both games is the little known Russo-Austro-Turkish War of 1735-39. Türkenkrieg dealt with the war between the Imperials (the Habsburg Austrian Empire) and the Ottoman Empire along the Danube. HGH investigates the theatre of the Ukraine, where the Russians attempted to destroy the power of the Crimean Tatars as a first step toward Peter the Great's dream of a warm water port.

On the Danube, the Ottoman Turks dealt a critical blow to Charles VI and the House of Habsburg, leading almost immediately to the War of the Austrian Succession (1740-48). In the Ukraine, things were different. Forgotten or dismissed as "futile" by historians, the campaigns of the Muscovites against the remnants of the Mongols' Golden Horde were in fact brutally effective.

8 scenarios and 1 Campaign

HGH is not a complete game. Although it is possible to play a few of the scenarios with the counter mix provided, HGH is intended to be an expansion module for TÃ¼rkenkrieg (1737-1739).

Name: Stratocracy
Description:
Stratocracy is a grand strategy empire building game.  2-8 players will construct a modular board that is unique from game to game and take turns exploring the board, and coming into conflict with each other.

Players have a limited set of moves and military pieces they may use during the game, and are trying to be the first to win via one of two listed victory conditions (one based on exploration, the other based on battle).

The turn sequence is broken into three phases (Treasury, Movement, and Battles) and each player completes his turn fully before it is passed to the next player.

Advanced rules are provided which gives players access to a set of nine nation cards with unique abilities that will alter their play-style, as well as rules for faster play.

Stratocracy is part of a series of print and play boardgames published through Bell of Lost Souls.  This series is provided as a downloadable pdf which includes everything needed to play except dice.  Players may download, print out the pieces, and start playing.  The game is designed to be enhanced with common playing pieces found in other games for those would prefer to not use counters.

STRATOCRACY is available FREE at BoLS Board Games: http://www.bolsboardgames.com

Name: Centrifuge
Description:
Centrifuge is a trick-taking game for 2 to 4 players, and was originally developed for the Decktet.  Centrifuge makes unusual use of the dual-suitedness of the Decktet cards (Each card valued 2-9 has an "upper" and a "lower" suit depicted on it.), in that the led card's upper suit will be positive, and its lower suit will be negative.  Subsequent cards may follow either suit, but those with the positive suit will be positive; those in the negative, negative.  Cards sporting both suits (such as the card that was led) cancel themselves, due to having both the positive and negative suit.

If the total value of the cards in the trick is positive, then the highest card wins the trick - even if it's an off-suit card.  If the total value of the cards in the trick is negative, then the lowest card wins the trick - even if it's an off-suit card.  The ability of an off-suit card to win is the equivalent of a trump mechanism in Centrifuge.  Another unusual feature is that it's possible for no one to win the trick.

Each player is playing to collect symbols of her own secret suit, indicated by an ace she was dealt at the beginning of the hand.

The game also supports partnership play (additionally offering a Cancellation variant).  The two-player game also offers a Playing for Both Teams variant.

Name: Ming Mang
Description:
Ming Mang is a traditional game of Tibetan origin played on a NxN board.

The setup has all cells on the edges are occupied. The left and upper side by one player, the right and bottom side by the other. All pieces move like the rook in Chess. A piece is captured when it is between two enemy pieces - irrespective of the number of empty cells between the pieces. Captured pieces are converted to the color of the captor. Thus, although very unknown in Tibet, Othello (Reversi) pieces would work well.

When played on a 8 x 8 - board each player would start with fourteen men on the board and 14 in reserve to replace captured enemy pieces.

Name: Apit-Sodok
Description: Apit-Sodok (Malaysia) or Mak-yek (Birma) is played on a 8 by 8 board with sixteen pieces on each side. In the initial setting pieces are covering the first and third row in front of the player. Pieces move like the rook in Chess. Capturing is both by interception (custodian capture) and intervention (when a friendly piece is moved between two or more hostile ones).

Name: Road Racer
Description:
[From the box back]

Start your engines in this high-rolling dice game that brings out the risky racer in all of us.  Should you play it safe?  Or risk it all with just one more roll?  Pace your race to score 5000 miles as quickly as you can - but LOOK OUT!  You could spin out nd lose it all.  Beat the other racers past the finish line and head fr the winner's circle.  Ready?  Set?  Roll!

Contents:
4 Custom Dice
1 Bonus Dice
Score Pad
Rules of Play

Name: Alpha Cards: The Game of Games
Description: This deck of 100 cards, each containing a letter and a point value except the two wild Alpha cards, can be used to play a variety of word games.  Included with the game are instructions to play Alpha Cards and Team Alpha Cards (beginner and expert); Crazy Alpha, Alphataire, Five Card Alpha, and Five Letter Alpha.

Name: Der kleine U-Boot-Kommandant
Description:
The complete title including subtitle is "Der kleine U-Boot-Kommandant auf großer Fahrt nach Engelland" which literally sounds like "The little U-Boat-commander on his speed to England"but figuratively is saying, "...on the great mission against England."

This may be the first U-Boat game ever published (1940) and is inspired by the previous successes (real and propagandistic) of the German submarine force.
Aim of the game is to shoot enemy vessels with a spring driven torpedo.

Name: M Squad
Description:
M Squad is a roll-and-move game featuring the famous TV-series of the late 50ies/early 60ies with male actor Lee Marvin starring and depicted on the box cover.

It's a light family game using the box inlay as game board.

You have to travel the town with small plastic cars in order to locate the daughter of a famous citizen who became a victim of a criminal act.

If you find some hints you can cover the name of the girl with small discs on the various locations. 
The player who succeeds the first to cover the whole name with his discs is the winner of the game.

Name: Yvio: Freibeuter der Karibik
Description:
"Freibeuter der Karibik" is one of the first boardgame modules published for the YVIO game console.

The "Yvies" discs have to be inserted into pirate sailing ships, and you begin your mission to be the first player to gain 10 victory points (standard game).

Well-known ports like Cartagena or San Juan have to be visited to earn money in order to acquire equipment for your ships.
Every port requires two commodities and offers two others.
The longer the journey and the more valuable your cargo the larger your profit - but beware: What also becomes larger is the possibility to be attacked by rival pirates !
Some ports are the home of traders where you can buy equipment. These equipments not only give you victory points but also help your mission: Sails shorten your journey time and help to flee rivals, cannons help to fight them, sailors help in melee combat and larger trunks help to enlarge your profits.
And if you are too much playing for your own profit all the players loose if the rival pirates occupy at least 5 ports!

The game offers much more, and all is controlled via the YVIO console in the middle of the game board, which interacts with the ships and their "YVIES" and the electronic devices embedded in the game board and - last but not least - with the boardgame players.

And there is still enough boardgame feeling with the game board, the ship pawns you move, a cardboard ship mat with cardboard equipment and cardboard dubloons.

You don't have to learn rules, as the console steers you via an introductionary game through the shallows of the beginner in multilingual speech if so desired.

Name: Yvio
Description:
YVIO is according to the developers "the best of two worlds".

The 2 worlds they refer to are electronic and board gaming.
YVIO is an electronic console which is the basic requirement for different board games which act together with the components of these.

The console itself is equipped with a lot of little LED-bulbs, an SD-card-slot, a loudspeaker and some expansion possibilities. It is further accompanied by 4 coloured disks which have to be inserted into the playing pawns of the different games. They communicate via remote access with the console.
You have to buy boardgames containing the SD-cards with the gaming software and the traditional boardgame accessories.
The boards of the games contain electronic devices too, and these connect to the console via the disks, called "Yvies".
With every game comes also a so called "Yvio skin" which is laid onto the top of the console depicting the symbols for the keys you have to press to play the game and the action segments lit up by the LEDs.

If you liked the game "Die Insel" from the Ravensburger editors, Yvio is your cup of tea, but it offers much more different options and games.

Name: Kod DaVinci, po sledam velikih tayn
Description:
Card game with a field. In game it is necessary to create hiding places and to hide in them relics from other players. Players can open anothers hiding places, and also place in the hiding places of a trap. The board makes hierarchy of monks of secret order.

Game is published under the license for book Dan Brown "The Da Vinci Code".

Game structure: 
Cards: 
Relics - 12, 
Traps - 36, 
Breaking - 36, 
Unexpectedness - 8, 
Professional - 8, 
Score Points - 8, 
Relics - 12, 
Counters of players - 8

Field - 1

Name: Stacks
Description:
This game is played on an empty 4x4 board. Each player starts with 24 pieces off board. On each turn, each player must do one of the following actions:
- Drop a stack of 1, 2 or 3 stones into an empty cell.
- Drop any number of stones on top of a friendly stack.
- Move a stack into an adjacent (orthogonal or diagonal) empty cell. However, after the move the stack loses one stone (stacks of size 1 cannot move).
- Move into and capture an adjacent enemy stack of smaller size (so stacks of size 1 cannot capture either). The attacking stack loses the number of stones equal to the captured stack plus one.

All stones return to the players reserves. A player cannot make partial attacks, he must move all the stones of the attacking stack.

Wins the player that makes a 4 in-a-row containing friendly stacks with the same size (like 4 stacks of size 3) or an equal, step-wise increment from start to end of the row (e.g., 1-2-3-4, 1-3-5-7, 2-5-8-11).

Name: Triomph
Description:
The objective of this abstract game is to capture the 4 center spots on the board and hold them for one round.

You use cards to move your pieces over the board and to attack other pieces (moving and attack cards are different). So you are limitied in your options by the cards you draw.

By forming "trios" (three of your stones with different colours) you can make your pieces stronger, but you will slow them down at the same time.

Name: Kvinnofrågor
Description:
Translated "Kvinnofrågor" means Questions about Womens issues.

Kvinnofrågor is an educational game where two or more teams answer questions about feminism, equality and womens history.

There are one hundred cards, each depicting a person or an organisation. Examples of cards: Emma Goldman, Wonder Woman, Grupp 8, Aung San Suu Kyi, Gerd Brantenberg, Le tigre. 
On the back of the cards are five questions worth different points.

Fifteen of the 100 cards are randomly drawn from the deck and placed with the portrait side up. One by one, the cards are picked up and the teams tries to answer the questions on it. The team with the most points wins the card. When all questions on ten of the fifteen cards have been answered, the team that has won the most cards wins.

Game content:
- Rule sheet
- 100 Cards
- 34 page book with information about the people and organisations depicted on the cards.

This game is right now only avalible in swedish. (januari 2009)

Publishers site:
http://www.athenaspel.se

Name: Unser Bauernhof
Description:
A simple game suitable for very young kids (Ages 4 and up): you race around the range using a color die. Collect as much animals from the range before the sun sets (or there are no more animals left).

But caution! If you don't build a fence for your animals, the animals might run back to the range.

Name: Reservat
Description:
This is a pentacube placement game.  At the start of the game, the players choose twelve pieces apiece.  They then take turns placing the pieces squarely into the box so that nothing protrudes above the top edge.

Players try to form "reserves," which are holes in the structure that may only be filled by pieces that they themselves hold.

A player who passes is eliminated and loses.  Every piece left in the loser's hand counts as a point for the winner, but the other player may continue placing pieces in order to rack up extra points, one per piece so placed.

There are minor variants of this game in the rule booklet for three and four players, as well as a quick game called "Home and Dry" for two through 12(!) players.  There was apparently also a separately obtainable second booklet, entitled "Spiele mit Pentakuben," that provided eight additional games and a variety of puzzles that could be built with the pentacubes.

Name: Redline
Description:
This is a square tile placement game in which every tile has one or more red lines that cross one, two, or three of its edges or vertices.  Additionally, each tile has either a yellow or a blue background.

After an initial deal, tiles must be placed so as to directly continue some red line already in play, while alternating the background color from that of the tile whose line is being continued.  
 An extra tile may be pulled from the kitty when the player creates a line of three or more tiles of the same background color, or four or more tiles of alternating background colors.  The winner is the last player able to place a tile.  There is a non-compulsory scoring system that may be used.

Unlike most other tile-laying games of this sort, the player is not required to place a new tile so that its edge is flush against a previous tile, but can also place a tile vertex-to-vertex, provided that the edges are collinear with the tile whose red line is being continued.

Name: Paris-Beijing: The Ultimate Geography Challenge
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Open the suitcase and discover the world.

An exciting game in which you must win the Paris-Beijing race using your knowledge in geography and as a traveler.  Your visual skills and your reflexes will be put to the test.  Not a great geographer?  No matter.  This game can be played by everyone and it will bring you hours of fun.

Contents : board, 165 question cards, 72 country cards, 6 chips, 1 die, hourglass and instructions

Ages 10 and up

Name: Them & Us
Description:
A deliberately provocative game that pitches men against women. Each team takes turns to shout out responses to stereotypical topics. It could be "Brands of Make-Up", "Fast Cars", or "Annoying Male Habits". But only answers matching those on the card score points!

Frantic, funny and frequently outspoken, this game pitches brawn against beauty in a contest to determine the superior sex!

Name: The Big Score!
Description:
The Big Score! is a game designed to teach the basics of credit scoring to beginning loan originators, underwriters, and loan processors.  It can be played by 2 - 8 individuals or teams.

Each player begins at "Start" with 400 credit score points.  Players then move around the board to each category and must answer questions: minimum 50 points/maximum 125 points in each category.  Each question is worth 25 points.  Players may encounter either Credit Scoring Advances or Obstacles on their way to each category or while in a category.  Advances gain points; obstacles lose points.  The first player to have accumulated the most credit score points (900 being a perfect score) from EACH category must make their way to "Finish" to win the game.

The game is produced by the United Guaranty Corporation, a member company of American International Group (AIG).

Name: Homo Pfifficus
Description:
The players must climb through the stages of human development from Pliopithecus to Homo Pfifficus. The development is represented by a 12-field-scale.

In each round, the top card is turned over and read aloud. Then, each player decides on a number from 0 to 9 and takes the corresponding number of chips into their fist. These are revealed simultaneously and the pieces are moved on the game board according to the instructions on the playing card (e.g. "the highest number remains, all others move forward"). The game ends when a player reaches the last field (Homo Pfifficus) with their figure and they are declared the winner. The game also ends after 12 rounds of play where the player who reached the highest level of development (i.e. most advanced) wins.

Originally published in spielbox 1992 #6.

Name: Minuteman; Don't Tread On Me
Description: Wargaming rules for the American Revolutionary War period 1775-1781. Emphasizes desertion rate, fire & movement and a nearly diceless combat resolution system based on historical unit firepower. Apparently self-published by Ken Ray and Scotty Bowden in August 1974.

Name: Penalty
Description:
In Penalty, players compete in an ice hockey match.

The game is played over three periods (or rounds). Each player starts a period with coins valued 5 (x1), 2 (x5), and 1 (x10). Each period consists of several duels. In a duel, the player who reveals the highest value of coins in their hand wins the duel and moves the puck down the ice (the game board). However, if they reveal at least 3 coins more than their opponent, they lose the duel and the other player gets to move the puck instead.  If a player manages to move the puck off of the ice, they score a goal. If one player has no more coins after a duel, the period ends, but first, the opponent may now move the puck according to the number of their remaining coins. The game ends after three periods have been played and the player who scored the most goals wins.

Originally published as Spielbox Edition No.2 in Spielbox issue 2/1993.

Name: Way Back When in History 1400-1865
Description: Answer a question about the time period you are in to roll the die and move through history to win.  Start with the Explorers, move on to the American Colonies, then the American Revolution, the Constitution, and finally the Civil War.  Each card has five questions, one for each time period.

Name: What's The Point?
Description: Match your decimal, fraction, and percentage cards to your spin to turn in those cards.  Get rid of all your cards to win!

Name: Kamasutra Game
Description: In this game you have 5 dice (home location [couch, chair and the like], male position, female position, action [touch, kiss and the like], body part). Cast the dice, try to accomplish the position and obtain the most Victory Points.

Name: Race Duel S
Description:
Race Duel S pits two drivers against each other on a variety of different tracks. You must win three races to emerge triumphant but strategic losses will help you extend the competition and win the most Prize Money.

Race duel S includes eighteen track cards that can be used to create five race circuits. Each track card has limits depending on form, weather and condition. Drivers must choose how aggressively they will drive each segment to achieve their goal.

The only thing not included are a D6 die and markers for the record sheets.

Available below in the file section.

Name: The Million Dollar Challenge
Description:
The Million Dollar Challenge is a new board game based on the teachings of legendary commodities trader Larry Williams, which allows players to enter trades using actual market indicators, such as ADX and Percent R. You'll wait for the correct entry, place your buy/sell order and exit at an opportune time.

This fun and popular board game improves the family's understanding of the many considerations that go into trading the markets.

Begin by moving around the board collecting entry and indicator cards. Determine which market you'll enter by rolling the market die. Markets include gold, T-bonds, wheat, copper, coffee, S&P 500 and more. Wager your contracts, place your protective stop and enter the trade. Watch for changing market conditions. Reach an exit space to determine if your trade is profitable.

Name: Generals: A trivia Game celebrating the heritage of The Salvation Army
Description:
Generals is a trivia game about the history of The Salvation Army. Your pawn is an early leader of The Salvation Army. You roll dice to move around the board and answer questions related to the early history of The Salvation Army.

There are spaces which you would draw a "Scalawags or Scoundrel" card. This card asks you a relevant personal question for you to talk about with the other players.

The board is adapted from the illustration that accompanies William Booth's, the founder and first General of The Salvation Army, book, "In Darkest England and the Way Out."

Name: Tour: Cycle Free
Description:
The long-awaited follow up to Luke Morris' 2006 game "Tour", Cycle Free throws the dice out of the window and tears up the race track grids. Instead, up to six team managers will base their strategies on the strengths of their riders, their remaining energy, their daily form and the race terrain.
The focus of the game is on positioning in the peloton, conserving energy and timing the perfect attacks.  When the brave cyclists attack off the front of the peloton, the group may be slow to react but as the kilometres go past, and the breakaway group starts to tire, the chase is on!

Tour: Cycle Free is as much an RPG and strategy game as it is a race.

Name: Ron & Bones
Description:
Welcome to RON and BONES cabin boy:
The most innovative and impressive strategy game of the 7 seas. RON and BONES is a simultaneous cards and miniatures´ game; where long and tedious waits ended between turns.You must prepare your game strategy considering next adversary movements and all boarding chaos. 
Your adversary and you are playing simultaneous strategies so, think quick and over all, hit even faster!! 
Save as much rum and coins as possible to hire your own crew to battle against your adversaries. But be careful! In this game, your enemy can hit you before you have time to draw your sword. Lets your adversary breath away and throw him overboard before he can reorganize his defences, and if you can not do that…bribe his crew!!

Bienvenido grumete a RON AND BONES:
El más innovador e impactante juego de estrategia de los 7 mares. RON AND BONES es un juego de figuras y cartas simultáneo; donde se acabaron las pesadas esperas entre turnos.
Tendrás que preparar tu estrategia teniendo en cuenta los próximos movimientos de tu rival y el caos de un abordaje. Tú y tu adversario jugaréis de forma simultánea asi que, piensa rapido y sobre todo ¡!golpea mas rápido todavía!!
Hazte con mucho ron y suficientes doblones para contratar a tu tripulación y enfréntate a tus adversarios. Pero ten cuidado!. En este juego el enemigo puede atacarte antes de que te de tiempo siquiera a desenvainar.
No des respiro a tu rival y lánzale por la borda antes de que organice su defensa, y si no puedes...¡¡¡soborna a su tripulación!!!.

Name: Cymbergaj
Description:
Cymbergaj (pronounced like 'tsim-berr-guy') is a traditional tabletop game that simulates European football (soccer). It was quite popular in schools, the matches took place on classroom desks during breaks between classes.

Each of two players has a team of footballists represented by coins. There's one big coin 'the goalkeeper' and three medium-sized coins 'field players' in each team. To distinguish between teams one of them is 'heads up' the other is 'tails up'. There is also one small coin in use - representing the ball. The goals are usually gaps between two boxes or books each.

The game mechanics is similar to Carrom or PitchCar - players finger-flick their respective team coins to hit the ball and eventually to score points by shooting goals. The rules of fair and foul plays depend on the variant of the game. And the variants are numerous!

Name: Nyomozó Budapesten
Description:
In this game players are detectives. They travel around Budapest to acquire every small piece of information. They can make it difficult for the other players by giving them false information. At the end of the game each player writes down his/her ideas about the solution of the mysterious crime; the closest one wins.

There are 30 scenarios given for this game.

Name: Góbé
Description: There are two rounds in this game. In the first round players put down hexagon tiles of their color, In the second round they put down white tiles and remove their tiles, and get points according the number of neighbors of the removed tiles. The board, which is made of these hexagon tiles, always has to remain connected.

Name: Harmat
Description: In this monopoly-type game the result of the dice-roll determines only the direction of the movement on the board (every field has at most six neighbors). The properties are companies and players can only buy shares of the companies.

Name: Bolsevíta
Description: Satiric monopoly-type game about the communism in Hungary.

Name: Logosz
Description: Trivia game about the old and the new testament.

Name: Vállalkozz okosan
Description: The title refers to the classic Hungarian boardgame GazdÃ¡lkodj Okosan!, where you have to manage your money smartly. Here players lead a company, hence they have to manage their money and the company's money too.

Name: Az abakusztól az internetig: informatikai társasjáték
Description:
The players can acquire parts of a computer answering questions about the basics and the history of computers and internet.

Play with ease from @z abacus to @z Internet! 1000 questions, in 6 topics, in 3 levels of difficulty, according to the age and preparation of the players. It encompasses the knowledge of computer technology and information technology, and guides you from the basics to the ever-developing world of today. We can walk this path in such a way that in the middle of the enjoyable and exciting game, our knowledge increases imperceptibly, the computer becomes our friend, and the possibilities offered by technology open up before us. We especially recommend it: at school, for class or professional activities, for differentiation, for spending time at home, for free time activities, for preparing for competitions. Go to the world of IT!

Name: Jólaspilið
Description: In this game the players travel along a simple track in the Biblical areas, from Nazareth to Bethlehem, and to Egypt and back. The box is made out of steel and the pawns are magnetic.

Name: Pocket Modern Warfare
Description:
Pocket Modern Warfare is a free print and play simple table top game using top down paper minis from Junior General website that can be played virtually anywhere. Using the top down paper vehicles and soldiers from Junior General one can use the terrain available from the site or use any other manner of item to represent buildings and terrain on the table top.

The play is also simplified in easy rulers that are printed with the game that take care of movement and firing ranges. So no tape measures to carry around, just some dice and all the paper mini's you've printed.

For more free great minis visit:
http://www.juniorgeneral.org/

Name: Hustler Intercollegiate Football
Description: A solidly made tin Football Game that has a large roller at the top and a very nice graphic representation of a ball field. (Hustler also produced a Baseball Game of the same ilk.) That roller has a slot at the top of the game that shows results of the play depending on what is happening on the field. In other words with different field position the play yields different results.

Name: The Greatest Mission is the World
Description: The Greatest Mission is the World is a Risk-like in which players control "armies" of LDS missionaries in an attempt to get their missionaries into every country in the world. Players roll dice in battles determine which missionaries will get sent home and collect cards for victory which can be traded for more missionaries. Special interest is paid to Israel as the player who controls that region has access to the 12 Tribes to help win battles.

Name: LDSopoly
Description: LDSopoly is a Monopoly style game in which players complete for stewardship of LDS Temples. One player is chosen as the bishop who is in charge of all finances. As players move about the board and "visit the temples" they pay offerings for temples to those who have stewardship over them. The winner is the first to control all temples.

Name: Celestialzy
Description:
Celestialzy (pronounced celestial-zee) is an LDS dice rolling game somewhat similar to Yahtzee but with a few significant changes. Players roll five dice up to three times to score in 12 categories. The dice have symbols instead of numbers that are relevant to the LDS faith.

Sun - The Celestial Kingdom
Moon - The Terrestrial Kingdom
Stars - The Telestial Kingdom
Dipper - The Big Dipper "points the way" to the North Star.
Cloud - Earth (2nd Estate)
Comet - Messengers from God (Angels)

The scoring and categories used on the card are different from Yahtzee with some symbols being worth as much as 25 points per die. Also included are categories for rolling different dice (large and small universe). The player with the highest score wins, unless someone rolls five suns in which case that player wins immediately.

Name: Temples Chess
Description: Temples Chess is an LDS Collectible Card Game somewhat similar to Hera and Zeus or a card game version of Stratego. The players have customizable and expandable decks of cards illustrated with an LDS temple and chess piece (which dictates the card's movement). The cards are laid out face down in a 5x4 grid and are revealed when used or attacked. The goal is to find and capture your opponent's king.

Name: Temples Collectible Card Game
Description: Temples CCG is an LDS collectible card game somewhat similar to Magic: The Gathering. Cards feature pictures of LDS temples with indicators of Priesthood Power and required amount of genealogy cards needed to activate the card in battle. Players build their hands from an available 130 cards to have the most Priesthood Power. Kingdom Cards (sold in Booster packs) allow for an increase in Priesthood. Temples that are defeated go to the graveyard until one player emerges victorious.

Name: Christians and Saracens
Description: Christians and Saracens is a low-complexity wargame based on the Battle for Jerusalem. Up to six players can play as an army from the period (Britonian, Franks, or Saxon Crusaders or Turks, Arabs, or Egyptian Saracen). The goal is to break through your opponents' defenses while at the same time maintaining your own. The game is flexible enough to allow one defender the opportunity to beat three attackers (in a four player game).

Name: How to Host the Greatest Mission in the World Party Game
Description: How to Host the Greatest Mission in the World Party Game is an LDS storytelling game. Each player fills out a ballot and takes turns telling stories about their LDS Missionary Experience (whether full time or just telling a neighbor or coworker about the LDS Church). After stories are complete, the players use the ballots to vote on the stories. Blue ribbons are provided in the game for prizes.

Name: WinniM
Description:
A word card game in which you lay down and/or add to words from your hand.  The unique feature of WinniM is that each card can stand for a vowel or consonant, depending on which end is up.  The 105 cards have all possible combinations (5 x 21).  This adds an extra dimension: in addition to rearranging letters as you add to your words, you can flip the cards to change the letters in the word.  In the Wild version, you can also steal from and add to opponents' words as well.

When the deck runs out and no one can play any more, score for the number of cards you have on the table and for the length of each word, longer words giving many more points.

Name: Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing: Counting
Description:
This GAMES FOR GROWING -- Counting Game Set is designed to help your child learn to count, to learn different ways that numbers are written or shown, and to do simple adding and subtracting.  This learning is done in the way that children learn best -- through play.

Includes 3 decks of cards in different sizes, spinners, and a parent teaching guide with teaching tips and rules for 8 different games.

Name: Pas de Charge
Description:
Pas de Charge is a set of rules for Napoleonic Miniatures.
Rules covering the entire Napoleonic period.
Each player in turn pulls its overall initiative to make voluntary movements, spontaneous movements are carried out later.
After shots were fired artillery and fighting Melee.

Name: Bartender
Description:
Bartender is a card game in which players compete to make the most money by mixing fancy drinks. The fancier the drink, the more money it is worth. 
In Bartender, the table represents the bar, the deck of cards represents the store-room full of ingredients, and the cards in the players hands represent the ingredients the players are carrying from the store-room to the bar. 
Players must 'stock' the bar with the cards from their hand so that they can mix fancy drinks but unless they are careful, the other players can use those cards to mix their own drinks.
Bartender was designed as a bartender training aid. 
After a few plays, players will start to memorize the formulas for the over 50 real drinks depicted in the game.

Name: Impacto
Description:
Impacto is a set of rules for WWII Miniatures of 5mm.
The rules are a basic introduction to the game of miniatures.
Sequence of game is typical: simultaneous movement and fire.

Name: The Price of Freedom
Description: Price of Freedom can be played as a pen and paper role-playing game or as a hex and counter wargame.  It depicts a conflict between Soviet forces occupying America and resistance fighters.

Name: Zooloretto Exotic
Description:
Now the zoo becomes more exotic with the building of a new jungle experience path with strange animals from all over the world. These new exotic animals attract a large number of curious visitors.

The stands near these animals pay double because of the increased business. Of course, the other zoos also have their exotic animals to lure customers to them.

The player who creates exhibits that keep visitors in his zoo will earn bonus points at the end.

Expands:

    Zooloretto


Small Expansions:

     Chamaeleon (in Abacusspiele Katalog-Edition 10)


Home Page & Newsletter:

     www.zooloretto.com 


(German, English, Dutch, Hungarian, Spanish, Swedish)

Name: Pokémon Diamond and Pearl Battle Dome
Description: This game comes in a huge box, and builds up a multi-level tower measuring over two feet tall at 26 inches.  The game comes with five different Pokémon miniatures, and players choose which to play.  Each level of the tower features a different game usually representing a Pokémon-style showdown, culminating in the top level, where one player takes the cannon while the defending player controls his piece, trying not to be hit.

Name: Blood Sword
Description:
This game book series distinguishes itself from the other mainstream game books in various ways, adding up to the complexity of the rules and providing a combat system that is very similar to the miniatures combat system as used for instance in "Heroquest". Whenever there is a fight, a map is provided showing where the players and their foes are located, and players must resolve the fight using counters or miniatures.
The series supports up to four players; a single person may play with a powerful character, or a team of four people may play with a diversified group of less powerful characters (a Warrior, an Enchanter, a Sage and a Trickster). When multiple players participate, a single person is designated as the reader, and he or she must read the book aloud to the group; however, at certain points, different characters have to read sections to themselves privately, giving different knowledge to different people.

Name: Harigana
Description:
Harigana is a tile-laying word game for Japanese for 2 or more players. Tiles have hiragana syllable symbols rather than letters. The game is similar to Scrabble, but has some differences in the scoring system and some other differences to accommodate the Japanese language and the hiragana writing system.

The game was designed with Japanese language learners in mind, but can be played by Japanese speakers just as well. Japanese language learners should not hesitate to use a dictionary to help find words, and are advised to use an optional rule that awards bonus points if they can write kanji versions of words correctly (without looking them up, of course).

Name: Amore
Description:
Amore is a game for word lovers.  The deck has 108 cards: in each suit, the whole alphabet plus a second set of vowels; and 4 jokers.  Rarer letters are worth more points.

In the main Amore game, players are dealt a 9-card hand, and there are two rounds where each may discard 1-3 cards in exchange for new ones, similar to draw poker.  Then they score the highest-scoring words they can find.  Finally there is a bonus round, where hands are passed to the right, and those who can find a higher-scoring word than the original owner earn double the difference in points.  The game ends when the deck runs out.

There are also rules for Amore versions of Solitaire, Poker, Rummy, and "Crazy Aitches".

Name: Panzer Grenadier: North of Elsenborn
Description:
In September 1944, American troops rolled up to the German border having driven the fleeing Wehrmacht across France and Belgium. With the German Army crumbling, it appeared that the war might soon be over. But with a line of well-built fortifications and rapidly-deployed if raw reinforcements, the Germans stabilized their positions and would extend the war for another nine months.

Just south of the city of Aachen and just north of what would become the Elsenborn Ridge battlefield, the U.S. VII Corps attacked the German fortified line. Tanks of the 3rd Armored "Spearhead" Division steadily fought their way forward, backed by the veteran foot soldiers of the 1st and 9th Infantry Divisions. But fierce counterattacks finally blunted the advance; a full-scale invasion of German territory would have to wait until spring.

North of Elsenborn is a supplement for the Panzer Grenadier series. There are ten scenarios, or separate game situations, based on the battles of September 1944 between VII Corps and the German Seventh Army.

North of Elsenborn is sold BOTH via .pdf download and as a printed booklet; you only need one. The scenario book comes as a .pdf file that you'll need to print (or read off the screen) in order to play the scenarios, or you can order it as a booklet.

This game is part of the Panzer Grenadier series

Name: Martial World: Trainers Edition
Description:
So you are looking for a new type of card game. Maybe you want a to give a great gift, or the kids are way too active and you want to give them something new to do. Maybe you are a student, or a teacher or maybe you just enjoy most everything about the Martial Arts.

Well...

Welcome to Martial World's advanced "Trainers Edition" card game. "World Arts On Playing Cards"

As most, who are familiar with our games know, Martial World is an American style strategy game, which challenges players to win martial arts based sparring matches, using technique based "micro messaged" collectible cards. These combat strategy card games combine point-trick mechanics with card-capturing mechanics for deck building purposes. We call the deck building process "Building Your Form".

Each game box is designed for 2 to 5 players, intended for anyone ages 7 and up, comes with a single magnifying glass, (for a limited time) and no martial arts experience is necessary. Games are easy to learn, easy to develop flexible strategies, and average 90 minutes to establish a winner.

The fun is how cleverly the combination of multiple forms of martial arts technique terms, combine into round robin melees of attacks, blocks, and counter maneuvers. Here's how. Players spar in rounds which are initiated by the role of the dice and the round winners keeps the technique cards to add to their form. Another fun feature for players who are not sparring is that they may enjoy the micro messages which, for the white belt levels, display each school's core principals and values. You may even be surprised that most of these messages can be applied to every day life. So playing has good life benefits.

Ultimately our novel mechanics, embedded surprises, and our school based narrative features, provide players the opportunity to experience the many benefits of martial arts without the Epson salt. All may play and enjoy.

Designer's Note: All of our games are designed based on the history of real martial arts and may include many of each school's or style's myths. However folks, this is a game. Let's be honest, the only way to truly learn any form of Martial Arts is to do research and depending on your ideals, you will find a style which appeals you. Besides that, we are a USA based company and our games are made in America. We were originally published in 1992 but needed a lot of work. We kept pushing and in 2011 we were nominated for the Gaming Genius Awards as the best new card game. We were finalists but needed many upgrades. So we upgraded everything. Lastly we are members of our local gaming group CABS and have a membership with the Patent Tested Parent Approved association.

We welcome all feedback and recommendations. You may also zoom in to all of our pictures for samples of hidden surprises...

Name: Sonar Sea Battle
Description:
This game is an electronic game, similar to Battleship made by Radio Shack/Tandy.  The game board is set up similar to battleship with an electronic base and a divider to prevent the players from seeing their opponents grid.  Each player places 1 ship on their 11x11 grid, with the ship taking up one square.  Players have 3 options on a turn, the option of  placing sonar markers that indicate the general direction of the opponents ship (N/S/E/W),  firing missiles, or moving their ship (a maximum of 5 or 10 units per game, depending on the mode selected).

This a fun game that offers more slightly more complexity then Battleship, and more tense battles, since after 1 hit the game is over.

Name: Grand National: A Sweepstakes Game of Chance
Description: Featuring a copyright date of 1937, the box proclaims the game to be "complete with game * board * money * dice * horses * counters" and inside it indeed comes with all those parts. There are four horses -- red, blue, green and yellow -- in this game, which was released by Whitman Publishing Co.

Name: You're the Boss
Description:
From the publisher: 
This character education game teaches students how a real business works, as well as how employees directly contribute to the success or failure of the business. As the game progresses, profits and sales are affected by the behavior of employees under realistic business conditions. Students will recognize exactly which behaviors employers value in their employees. A fun game that reinforces good employee behavior and introduces common business terms. Includes teacher's booklet and reproducible score sheets.

Name: Brain Quest Card Game: Grades 5 & 6
Description: BRAIN QUEST card game comes with two decks.  The Questions deck is like a normal deck of playing cards with the addition of 4 trivia questions on them.  These can be used to play variants of Rummy, Solitaire, or Go Fish (instructions included.)  The Game Deck is used only with the BRAIN QUEST card game in which players draw from the Game Deck to get instructions on how to play their Questions cards.  The first player to get rid of his or her cards wins.

Name: LinguaFun!
Description:
From the game insert: "LinguaFun is an exciting learning tool that combines the effectiveness of audio language tapes and flash cards with the fun of many popular card games.  From the very first game you play, you will be speaking a foreign language using this unique and proven method.  Available in Italian, French, Spanish, German, and Ingles."

The game comes with cards and a pronunciation CD.  The cards come in three colors, are numbered with digits and the word for that number in the foreign language, and contain a word or phrase with a phonetic guide and English translation.  Rules come for using these cards to play Solitaire, Crazy Colors, Concentration, Gin Rummy, Go Fish, and War.

Name: Star Wars Clone Wars: Giant Card Games
Description: A deck of 32 cards, 4 sets of eight characters, featuring cartoon characters from the Star Wars Clone Wars animated film. Four games can be played: Grevious Hunt (Find the Queen); Use the Force (Pairs); Jedi Dual (Snap); and Clones (Rummy ie collect all four characters in a set).

Name: Coup D'Etat
Description:
The game contains a board, troop units (cardboard with plastic stands), and loyalty/deployment cards.A rulebook contains 2 pages of rules and some background to the theme.

The Board represents the city of Oja and each player represents a colonel in the Ojawan army. The first player to subdue the Presidential Guard and capture the palace wins.

Each player has 6 units under his command, 4 infantry and 2 tank. One tank will capture one infantry but two infantry capture one tank. Once captured the forces join your team.

However, through loyalty cards, you may find you attack with one of your units who promptly joins the other side as they play its loyalty card.

Name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King Board Game
Description:
One player takes the role of Mordor, and the opposing two to five players represent the Fellowship. Each player has a hand of cards taken from corresponding Mordor and Fellowship decks. The board shows tracks to record the progress of pieces representing The Army of Mordor, Merry and the Rohirrim, Gandalf and Pippin, Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli, and Frodo and Sam. Along the board tracks are seven locations to represent the key conflicts of the movie : Minas Tirith, Osgiliath, Shelob's Lair, etc.

Each player takes a turn to roll dice, accumulating movement points which will allow them to draw a Journey card (again from corresponding Mordor and Fellowship decks), this card then instructing them to draw battle cards, or sometimes to force the opposing side to discard cards. Players must manage their hand of cards bearing in mind the different cards that 'trump' in the conflicts to come.

As each of the locations is reached by the piece moving there, different rules apply to determine the exact course of combat. The goal of the Fellowship is to survive these encounters long enough until Frodo and Sam reach Mount Doom : Mordor has the opportunity to bring an early victory by defeating the Fellowship before the Ring is cast into the fire.

Though this may have a cover similar to The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, this was accepted to the database on the premise that it is an entirely different game.

Name: Say Cheese!
Description: If you’ve ever been inside a photo booth, you know what it’s like to act wild and crazy under the pressure of time. We’ve tried to capture a little bit of that frenetic feeling in this super fast dice game. As you quickly roll dice and look for matches, you’ll not only sharpen your reflexes, but you will also strengthen fine motor skills and visual acuity. Race to the photo finish in this dice game that plays out in a flash! Quickly roll your dice to match the characters on the photo booth cards. When you match a pair, shout "Cheese!" and collect the card. Win all the cards and you're picture perfect!

Name: Pool Sharks
Description: Shoot like a shark in this fast-paced underwater dexterity game. But watch out for the slippery Eight Ball - sink it too soon and you've sunk the game! Shoot the most balls into the fish pockets and you rule the pool.

Name: Alta
Description: Alta is a connection game played on a diamond-shaped board. An unusual twist of the game is that players place diagonal lines, called "switches," in the squares, which can be slanted either forward or backward. A player can either put a new switch on the board or "toggle" the direction of one of his switches. The object of the game is to connect two "nodes" at opposite corners of the board.
